patterns: Fungal infection, skin rash, nodal skin eruptions, dischromic  patches,
responses:
You may have Fungal infection.
Description:
 In humans, fungal infections occur when an invading fungus takes over an area of the body and is too much for the immune system to handle. Fungi can live in the air, soil, water, and plants. There are also some fungi that live naturally in the human body. Like many microbes, there are helpful fungi and harmful fungi. 
 Precautions:
 1. Personal hygiene
2. Avoid sharing personal items
3. Keep skin clean and dry
4. Use antifungal medications

patterns: Allergy, continuous sneezing, shivering, chills, watering from eyes
responses:
You may have Allergy
Description:
Allergies occur when your immune system reacts to a foreign substance, such as pollen, bee venom, pet dander, or certain foods, that doesn't cause a reaction in most people. Your immune system produces substances known as antibodies that identify a particular allergen as harmful, even though it isn't. When you come into contact with the allergen, your immune system's reaction can inflame your skin, sinuses, airways, or digestive system.
Precautions:
1. Avoid known allergens
2. Keep your living space clean and dust-free
3. Use air purifiers or filters
4. Take prescribed allergy medications

patterns: GERD, stomach pain, acidity, ulcers on tongue, vomiting, cough, chest pain,
responses:
You may have GERD
Description:
Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) occurs when stomach acid frequently flows back into the tube connecting your mouth and stomach (esophagus). This backwash (acid reflux) can irritate the lining of your esophagus, causing heartburn and other symptoms. GERD can lead to more serious conditions if left untreated.
Precautions:
1. Avoid trigger foods and beverages (such as spicy foods, caffeine, and alcohol)
2. Eat smaller, more frequent meals
3. Maintain a healthy weight
4. Elevate the head of your bed when sleeping

patterns: Chronic cholestasis,itching, vomiting, yellowish skin, nausea, loss of appetite, abdominal pain, yellowing of eyes
responses:
You may have Chronic Cholestasis
Description:
Chronic cholestasis is a condition characterized by the gradual obstruction of bile flow from the liver. This can lead to a buildup of bile in the liver, causing damage and various symptoms such as jaundice, itching, and fatigue. It can result from various liver diseases or bile duct obstructions.
Precautions:
1. Follow a low-fat diet
2. Stay hydrated
3. Avoid alcohol and certain medications that can worsen liver function
4. Regularly monitor liver function and seek medical care for any worsening symptoms.

patterns: Drug Reaction,itching, skin rash, stomach pain, burning micturition, spotting  urination
responses:
You may have Drug Reaction
Description:
A drug reaction occurs when your body reacts unfavorably to a medication. This reaction can range from mild symptoms like rash or nausea to severe allergic reactions that can be life-threatening. Drug reactions can be caused by various factors including individual sensitivity, dosage, or interactions with other medications.
Precautions:
1. Take medications as prescribed by your healthcare provider
2. Inform your healthcare provider about any known drug allergies
3. Monitor for any adverse reactions after starting a new medication
4. Seek immediate medical attention if you experience severe symptoms or allergic reactions.

Peptic ulcer disease is a condition characterized by painful sores or ulcers in the lining of the stomach, upper small intestine, or esophagus. These ulcers are often caused by an imbalance between stomach acid and the protective mucosal lining, leading to erosion of the tissue. Common symptoms include abdominal pain, bloating, and indigestion.
Precautions:
1. Avoid NSAIDs (nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) like aspirin and ibuprofen
2. Limit or avoid alcohol consumption
3. Quit smoking
4. Follow a healthy diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains

patterns: AIDS, muscle wasting, patches in throat, high fever, extra marital contacts
responses:
You may have AIDS
Description:
Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS) is a chronic, potentially life-threatening condition caused by the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV). HIV attacks the immune system, specifically CD4 cells, which are crucial for fighting off infections. As the immune system deteriorates, a person with HIV becomes more susceptible to opportunistic infections and may develop AIDS, the most advanced stage of HIV infection.
Precautions:
1. Practice safe sex by using condoms
2. Get tested for HIV regularly
3. Avoid sharing needles or syringes
4. Take antiretroviral therapy (ART) as prescribed by healthcare provider

patterns: Diabetes , fatigue, weight loss, restlessness, lethargy, irregular sugar level, blurred and distorted vision, obesity, excessive hunger, increased appetite, polyuria,
responses:
You may have Diabetes
Description:
Diabetes is a chronic condition characterized by high levels of glucose (sugar) in the blood. It occurs when the body either doesn't produce enough insulin or can't effectively use the insulin it produces. There are two main types of diabetes: type 1 and type 2. Type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune disease where the body attacks its insulin-producing cells, while type 2 diabetes develops when the body becomes resistant to insulin or doesn't produce enough insulin. Diabetes can lead to various complications if not managed properly, including heart disease, kidney damage, and nerve damage.
Precautions:
1. Monitor blood sugar levels regularly
2. Follow a balanced diet low in sugar and carbohydrates
3. Engage in regular physical activity
4. Take medications or insulin as prescribed by healthcare provider

patterns: Gastroenteritis, vomiting, sunken eyes, dehydration, diarrhoea
responses:
You may have Gastroenteritis
Description:
Gastroenteritis, often referred to as stomach flu, is an inflammation of the stomach and intestines typically caused by viral or bacterial infection. It is characterized by symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever. Gastroenteritis is highly contagious and can spread through contaminated food or water, close contact with infected individuals, or poor hygiene practices.
Precautions:
1. Practice good hand hygiene by washing hands frequently with soap and water
2. Avoid sharing utensils, food, or drinks with infected individuals
3. Stay hydrated by drinking plenty of fluids
4. Follow a bland diet and avoid spicy or greasy foods until symptoms improve

You may have Bronchial Asthma

Chronic respiratory condition causing airway inflammation and narrowing, leading to wheezing, coughing, and breathlessness.

4. Monitor lung function regularly.

patterns: Hypertension , headache, chest pain, dizziness, loss of balance, lack of concentration
responses:
You may have Hypertension.
Description:
 Hypertension, or high blood pressure, is a condition characterized by elevated pressure in the arteries. It often has no symptoms but can lead to serious health complications such as heart disease, stroke, and kidney failure if left untreated. Risk factors include unhealthy lifestyle choices, genetics, and certain medical conditions.
Precautions:
1. Adopt a low-sodium diet
2. Engage in regular physical activity
3. Maintain a healthy weight
4. Adhere to prescribed medications.

patterns: Cervical spondylosis, back pain, weakness in limbs, neck pain, dizziness, loss of balance
responses:
You may have Cervical Spondylosis.
Description:
Cervical spondylosis is a degenerative condition affecting the cervical spine (neck). It involves the wear and tear of the spinal discs and vertebrae, leading to symptoms such as neck pain, stiffness, and sometimes numbness or weakness in the arms or hands. Risk factors include aging, past neck injuries, and poor posture.
Precautions:
1. Practice good posture
2. Use proper ergonomics, especially when sitting for long periods
3. Engage in regular neck exercises and stretches
4. Seek medical advice for pain management and physical therapy.

patterns: Paralysis (brain hemorrhage), vomiting, headache, weakness of one body side, altered sensorium
responses:
You may have Paralysis.
Description:
Paralysis is a condition characterized by the loss of muscle function, commonly resulting from stroke or injury. It affects mobility and sensation, leading to difficulties in daily activities.
Precautions:
1. Seek immediate medical attention.
2. Adhere to prescribed treatment plans diligently.
3. Ensure safety at home and prevent accidents.
4. Consider using assistive devices for improved functionality.

patterns: Malaria, chills, vomiting, high fever, sweating, headache, nausea, muscle pain
responses:
You may have Malaria.
Description:
Malaria is a mosquito-borne infectious disease caused by parasites of the Plasmodium genus. It commonly presents with symptoms such as fever, chills, headache, and muscle aches. Severe cases can lead to complications like organ failure and death.
Precautions:
1. Use insect repellent and mosquito nets.
2. Take antimalarial medication as prescribed.
3. Wear protective clothing when outdoors.
4. Seek prompt medical treatment for symptoms.

Malaria is a mosquito-borne infectious disease caused by parasites of the Plasmodium genus. It commonly presents with symptoms such as fever, chills, headache, and muscle aches. Severe cases can lead to complications like organ failure and death.
Precautions:
1. Use insect repellent and mosquito nets.
2. Take antimalarial medication as prescribed.
3. Wear protective clothing when outdoors.
4. Seek prompt medical treatment for symptoms.

patterns: Chicken pox,itching, skin rash, fatigue, lethargy, high fever, headache, loss of appetite, mild fever, swelled lymph nodes, malaise, red spots over body
responses:
You may have Chickenpox.
Description:
Chickenpox is a highly contagious viral infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus. It typically presents with a characteristic rash of itchy, fluid-filled blisters, along with fever and fatigue. It can be especially severe in adults and those with weakened immune systems.
Precautions:
1. Avoid close contact with infected individuals.
2. Keep the affected person isolated until all blisters have crusted over.
3. Relieve itching with cool baths and calamine lotion.
4. Administer antiviral medications if recommended by a healthcare professional.

patterns: Typhoid, chills, vomiting, fatigue, high fever, nausea, constipation, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, toxic look (typhos), belly pain,
responses:
You may have Typhoid.
Description:
Typhoid is a bacterial infection caused by Salmonella typhi. It is transmitted through contaminated food or water and presents with symptoms such as high fever, headache, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Severe cases can lead to intestinal perforation and other complications.
Precautions:
1. Practice good hygiene, including handwashing.
2. Consume only safe, clean food and water.
3. Get vaccinated against typhoid if traveling to endemic areas.
4. Seek medical care promptly if experiencing symptoms.

patterns: Dimorphic hemmorhoids(piles), constipation, pain during bowel movements, pain in anal region, bloody stool, irritation in anus
responses:
You may have Dimorphic Hemorrhoids (Piles)
Description:
Swollen blood vessels in the rectal area, causing discomfort, pain, and sometimes bleeding during bowel movements.
Precautions:
1. Maintain a high-fiber diet to prevent constipation.
2. Stay hydrated and avoid straining during bowel movements.
3. Practice good anal hygiene and avoid using harsh toilet paper.
4. Consider topical treatments or medical interventions for symptom relief.

patterns: Heart attack, vomiting, breathlessness, sweating, chest pain
responses:
You may have a Heart Attack
Description:
Blockage of blood flow to the heart, causing chest pain, shortness of breath, and nausea.
Precautions:
1. Call emergency services immediately.
2. Chew and swallow aspirin if advised.
3. Stay calm and rest.
4. Avoid exertion until help arrives.

patterns: Varicose veins, fatigue, cramps, bruising, obesity, swollen legs, swollen blood vessels, prominent veins on calf
responses:
You may have Varicose Veins
Description:
Enlarged, twisted veins, usually in the legs, caused by weak or damaged vein walls and valves. Symptoms include bulging veins, leg swelling, and aching or heaviness.
Precautions:
1. Stay physically active to improve circulation.
2. Elevate legs when resting to reduce swelling.
3. Avoid prolonged sitting or standing.
4. Consider compression stockings for symptom relief.

patterns: Urinary tract infection, burning micturition, bladder discomfort, foul smell of urine, continuous feel of urine
responses:
You may have Urinary Tract Infection.
Description:
Bacterial infection affecting the urinary system, causing symptoms like frequent urination and burning sensation.
Precautions:
1. Drink plenty of water.
2. Practice good hygiene, especially after using the bathroom.
3. Avoid holding urine for too long.
4. Seek medical attention for proper diagnosis and treatment.

Highly contagious skin infection characterized by red sores or blisters that rupture and form a honey-colored crust.
Precautions:
1. Keep affected area clean and covered.
2. Avoid scratching or touching sores.
3. Wash hands frequently.
4. Use prescribed antibiotics as directed.

patterns: Fever or chills,cough,shortness of difficulty breathing,Fatigue,Muscle or body aches,Headache,New loss of taste or smell,Sore throat,Congestion or runny nose,Nausea or vomiting,Diarrhea

Viral illness with symptoms like fever, cough.
Precautions:
1. Wear masks.
2. Social distance.
3. Wash hands.

patterns: Fever or chills,cough,shortness of difficulty breathing,Fatigue,Muscle or body aches,Headache,New loss of taste or smell,Sore throat,Congestion or runny nose,Nausea or vomiting,Diarrhea
responses:
You may have Coronavirus (COVID-19).
Description:
Viral illness causing fever, cough.
Precautions:
1. Wear masks.
2. Social distance.
3. Wash hands.
4. Get vaccinated.

patterns: Trouble telling the difference between colors
responses:
You may have Color Blindness.
Description:
Color vision deficiency affecting perception of certain colors.
Precautions:
1. Use color-coded labels or apps for assistance.
2. Inform others about your condition.
3. Consider career options compatible with color blindness.
4. Get regular eye check-ups

patterns: Double vision,Hazy vision,Seeing a glare or halo around bright lights,Squinting,Headaches ,Eye strain (when your eyes feel tired or sore ,Trouble focusing when reading or looking at a computer.
responses:
You may have Refractive Errors.
Description:
Vision condition causing blurry vision due to abnormal eye shape.
Precautions:
1. Wear corrective lenses or glasses.
2. Avoid eye strain from screens.
3. Get regular eye exams.
4. Consider refractive surgery if advised.

patterns: seeing straight lines as wavy or crooked,seeing things that are not there (hallucinations),colours seeming less bright than they used to,objects looking smaller than normal
responses:
You may have Age-Related Macular Degeneration.
Description:
Progressive eye condition affecting central vision, common in older adults.
Precautions:
1. Quit smoking to reduce risk.
2. Eat a healthy diet rich in antioxidants.
3. Protect eyes from UV light.
4. Get regular eye check-ups.

patterns: Your vision is cloudy or blurry,You see double (this sometimes goes away as the cataract gets bigger),You see a halo around lights,You can't see well at night,Colors look faded.
responses:
You may have Cataract.
Description:
Clouding of the eye's lens leading to blurry vision and glare sensitivity.
Precautions:
1. Wear sunglasses to protect eyes from UV rays.
2. Quit smoking to reduce risk.
3. Get regular eye exams.
4. Consider cataract surgery if vision significantly affected.

patterns: Spots or dark strings floating in your vision (floaters)Blurred vision,Fluctuating visio,Dark or empty areas in your vision,Vision loss,
responses:
You may have Diabetic Retinopathy.
Description:
Eye condition caused by diabetes, leading to damage to the blood vessels in the retina.
Precautions:
1. Control blood sugar levels.
2. Monitor blood pressure and cholesterol.
3. Get regular eye exams.
4. Seek treatment promptly to prevent vision loss.

patterns: Severe headache,Severe eye pain,Nausea or vomiting,Blurred vision,Halos or colored rings around lights,Eye redness
responses:
You may have Glaucoma.
Description:
Eye condition characterized by damage to the optic nerve, often associated with high intraocular pressure.
Precautions:
1. Attend regular eye check-ups.
2. Use prescribed eye drops as directed.
3. Protect eyes from injury.
4. Maintain a healthy lifestyle.

patterns: An eye that wanders inward or outward,Eyes that appear to not work together,Poor depth perception,Squinting or shutting an eye,Head tilting,Abnormal results of vision screening tests.
responses:
You may have Amblyopia.
Description:
'Lazy eye' condition with reduced vision in one eye.
Precautions:
1. Early detection crucial.
2. Use patching or blurring techniques.
3. Regular child eye check-ups.
4. Vision therapy advised.

patterns: Eyes that don't look in the same direction at the same time,Eyes that don't move together,Squinting or closing one eye in bright sunlight,Tilting or turning the head to look at an object,Bumping into things
responses:
You may have Strabismus.
Description:
Condition where the eyes do not align properly and point in different directions.
Precautions:
1. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential.
2. Use corrective lenses or eye exercises.
3. Regular eye check-ups.
4. Consider surgery in severe cases

patterns: Blood or blood clots in the urine,Pain or burning sensation during urination,Frequent urination,Feeling the need to urinate many times throughout the nightFeeling the need to urinate, but not being able to pass urine,Lower back pain on 1 side of the body
responses:
You may have Bladder Cancer.
Description:
Malignant growth in the bladder lining, often causing blood in urine and urinary frequency.
Precautions:
1. Avoid smoking and exposure to chemicals.
2. Stay hydrated and maintain a healthy diet.
3. Attend regular check-ups for early detection.
4. Seek medical advice for symptoms like blood in urine.

patterns: New lump in the breast or underarm (armpit),Thickening or swelling of part of the breast,Irritation or dimpling of breast skin,Redness or flaky skin in the nipple area or the breast,Pulling in of the nipple or pain in the nipple area.
responses:
You may have Breast Cancer.
Description:
Malignant tumor formation in the breast tissues, often presenting as a lump or abnormal changes in breast appearance.
Precautions:
1. Perform regular breast self-exams.
2. Attend mammography screenings as recommended.
3. Maintain a healthy lifestyle with regular exercise and balanced diet.
4. Seek medical evaluation for any breast changes or concerns.

patterns: A change in bowel habits,Diarrhea, constipation, or feeling that the bowel does not empty, completely Bright red or very dark blood in the stool ,Stools that look narrower or thinner than normal,Discomfort in the abdomen, including frequent gas pains, bloating, fullness, and cramps.
responses:
You may have Colorectal Cancer.
Description:
Cancerous growth in the colon or rectum, often presenting with changes in bowel habits and rectal bleeding.
Precautions:
Adopt a high-fiber diet, undergo regular screenings, stay physically active, consult a doctor for persistent symptoms.

patterns: Blood in the urine (hematuria),Low back pain on one side (not caused by injury),A mass (lump) on the side or lower back,Fatigue (tiredness),Loss of appetite,Weight loss not caused by dieting,Fever that is not caused by an infection and that doesn't go away.
responses:
You may have Kidney Cancer.
Description:
Abnormal cell growth in the kidneys, leading to symptoms like blood in urine and abdominal pain.
Precautions:
Maintain a healthy weight, stay hydrated, attend regular check-ups, seek medical advice for concerning symptoms.

patterns: Coughing that gets worse or doesn't go away,Chest pain,Shortness of breath Wheezing,Coughing up blood,Feeling very tired all the time,Weight loss with no known cause.
responses:
You may have Lung Cancer.
Description:
Malignant growth in the lungs, often associated with smoking or exposure to carcinogens.
Precautions:
Avoid smoking, seek early detection through screenings, maintain a healthy lifestyle, consult a healthcare professional for symptoms.
